Ops.Name: err
Ops.Doc: Fail immediately.

Ops.Name: sha256
Ops.Doc: SHA256 hash of value A, yields [32]byte

Ops.Name: keccak256
Ops.Doc: Keccak256 hash of value A, yields [32]byte

Ops.Name: sha512_256
Ops.Doc: SHA512_256 hash of value A, yields [32]byte

Ops.Name: ed25519verify
Ops.Doc: for (data A, signature B, pubkey C) verify the signature of ("ProgData" || program_hash || data) against the pubkey => {0 or 1}
Ops.DocExtra: The 32 byte public key is the last element on the stack, preceded by the 64 byte signature at the second-to-last element on the stack, preceded by the data which was signed at the third-to-last element on the stack.

Ops.Name: ecdsa_verify
Ops.Doc: for (data A, signature B, C and pubkey D, E) verify the signature of the data against the pubkey => {0 or 1}
Ops.DocExtra: The 32 byte Y-component of a public key is the last element on the stack, preceded by X-component of a pubkey, preceded by S and R components of a signature, preceded by the data that is fifth element on the stack. All values are big-endian encoded. The signed data must be 32 bytes long, and signatures in lower-S form are only accepted.

Ops.Name: ecdsa_pk_decompress
Ops.Doc: decompress pubkey A into components X, Y
Ops.DocExtra: The 33 byte public key in a compressed form to be decompressed into X and Y (top) components. All values are big-endian encoded.

Ops.Name: ecdsa_pk_recover
Ops.Doc: for (data A, recovery id B, signature C, D) recover a public key
Ops.DocExtra: S (top) and R elements of a signature, recovery id and data (bottom) are expected on the stack and used to deriver a public key. All values are big-endian encoded. The signed data must be 32 bytes long.

Ops.Doc: A plus B. Fail on overflow.
Ops.DocExtra: Overflow is an error condition which halts execution and fails the transaction. Full precision is available from `addw`.

Ops.Doc: A minus B. Fail if B > A.
A divided by B (truncated division). Fail if B == 0.
Ops.DocExtra: `divmodw` is available to divide the two-element values produced by `mulw` and `addw`.

Ops.Doc: A times B. Fail on overflow.
Ops.DocExtra: Overflow is an error condition which halts execution and fails the transaction. Full precision is available from `mulw`.

Ops.Name: <
Ops.Doc: A less than B => {0 or 1}

Ops.Name: >
Ops.Doc: A greater than B => {0 or 1}

Ops.Name: <=
Ops.Doc: A less than or equal to B => {0 or 1}

Ops.Name: >=
Ops.Doc: A greater than or equal to B => {0 or 1}

Ops.Name: &&
Ops.Doc: A is not zero and B is not zero => {0 or 1}
A is not zero or B is not zero => {0 or 1}
A is equal to B => {0 or 1}
A is not equal to B => {0 or 1}
A == 0 yields 1; else 0

Ops.Name: len
Ops.Doc: yields length of byte value A

Ops.Name: itob
Ops.Doc: converts uint64 A to big-endian byte array, always of length 8

Ops.Name: btoi
Ops.Doc: converts big-endian byte array A to uint64. Fails if len(A) > 8. Padded by leading 0s if len(A) < 8.
Ops.DocExtra: `btoi` fails if the input is longer than 8 bytes.

Ops.Doc: A modulo B. Fail if B == 0.
A bitwise-or B

Ops.Name: &
Ops.Doc: A bitwise-and B
A bitwise-xor B
bitwise invert value A

Ops.Name: mulw
Ops.Doc: A times B as a 128-bit result in two uint64s. X is the high 64 bits, Y is the low

Ops.Name: addw
Ops.Doc: A plus B as a 128-bit result. X is the carry-bit, Y is the low-order 64 bits.

Ops.Name: divmodw
Ops.Doc: W,X = (A,B / C,D); Y,Z = (A,B modulo C,D)
Ops.DocExtra: The notation J,K indicates that two uint64 values J and K are interpreted as a uint128 value, with J as the high uint64 and K the low.

Ops.Name: intcblock
Ops.Doc: prepare block of uint64 constants for use by intc
Ops.DocExtra: `intcblock` loads following program bytes into an array of integer constants in the evaluator. These integer constants can be referred to by `intc` and `intc_*` which will push the value onto the stack. Subsequent calls to `intcblock` reset and replace the integer constants available to the script.

ImmediateNote.Comment: a block of int constant values
ImmediateNote.Name: UINT ...

Ops.Name: intc
Ops.Doc: Ith constant from intcblock

Ops.Name: intc_0
Ops.Doc: constant 0 from intcblock

Ops.Name: intc_1
Ops.Doc: constant 1 from intcblock

Ops.Name: intc_2
Ops.Doc: constant 2 from intcblock

Ops.Name: intc_3
Ops.Doc: constant 3 from intcblock

Ops.Name: bytecblock
Ops.Doc: prepare block of byte-array constants for use by bytec
Ops.DocExtra: `bytecblock` loads the following program bytes into an array of byte-array constants in the evaluator. These constants can be referred to by `bytec` and `bytec_*` which will push the value onto the stack. Subsequent calls to `bytecblock` reset and replace the bytes constants available to the script.

ImmediateNote.Comment: a block of byte constant values
ImmediateNote.Name: BYTES ...

Ops.Name: bytec
Ops.Doc: Ith constant from bytecblock

Ops.Name: bytec_0
Ops.Doc: constant 0 from bytecblock

Ops.Name: bytec_1
Ops.Doc: constant 1 from bytecblock

Ops.Name: bytec_2
Ops.Doc: constant 2 from bytecblock

Ops.Name: bytec_3
Ops.Doc: constant 3 from bytecblock

Ops.Name: arg
Ops.Doc: Nth LogicSig argument

Ops.Name: arg_0
Ops.Doc: LogicSig argument 0

Ops.Name: arg_1
Ops.Doc: LogicSig argument 1

Ops.Name: arg_2
Ops.Doc: LogicSig argument 2

Ops.Name: arg_3
Ops.Doc: LogicSig argument 3

Ops.Name: txn
Ops.Doc: field F of current transaction

Ops.Name: global
Ops.Doc: global field F

Ops.Name: gtxn
Ops.Doc: field F of the Tth transaction in the current group
Ops.DocExtra: for notes on transaction fields available, see `txn`. If this transaction is _i_ in the group, `gtxn i field` is equivalent to `txn field`.

Ops.Name: load
Ops.Doc: Ith scratch space value. All scratch spaces are 0 at program start.

ImmediateNote.Comment: position in scratch space to load from
ImmediateNote.Name: I

Ops.Name: store
Ops.Doc: store A to the Ith scratch space

ImmediateNote.Comment: position in scratch space to store to
ImmediateNote.Name: I

Ops.Name: txna
Ops.Doc:
Ith value of the array field F of the current transaction
`txna` can be called using `txn` with 2 immediates.

Ops.Name: gtxna
Ops.Doc:
Ith value of the array field F from the Tth transaction in the current group
`gtxna` can be called using `gtxn` with 3 immediates.

Ops.Name: gtxns
Ops.Doc: field F of the Ath transaction in the current group
Ops.DocExtra: for notes on transaction fields available, see `txn`. If top of stack is _i_, `gtxns field` is equivalent to `gtxn _i_ field`. gtxns exists so that _i_ can be calculated, often based on the index of the current transaction.

Ops.Name: gtxnsa
Ops.Doc:
Ith value of the array field F from the Ath transaction in the current group
`gtxnsa` can be called using `gtxns` with 2 immediates.

Ops.Name: gload
Ops.Doc: Ith scratch space value of the Tth transaction in the current group
Ops.DocExtra: `gload` fails unless the requested transaction is an ApplicationCall and T < GroupIndex.

ImmediateNote.Comment: position in scratch space to load from
ImmediateNote.Name: I

Ops.Name: gloads
Ops.Doc: Ith scratch space value of the Ath transaction in the current group
Ops.DocExtra: `gloads` fails unless the requested transaction is an ApplicationCall and A < GroupIndex.

ImmediateNote.Comment: position in scratch space to load from
ImmediateNote.Name: I

Ops.Name: gaid
Ops.Doc: ID of the asset or application created in the Tth transaction of the current group
Ops.DocExtra: `gaid` fails unless the requested transaction created an asset or application and T < GroupIndex.

Ops.Name: gaids
Ops.Doc: ID of the asset or application created in the Ath transaction of the current group
Ops.DocExtra: `gaids` fails unless the requested transaction created an asset or application and A < GroupIndex.

Ops.Name: loads
Ops.Doc: Ath scratch space value.  All scratch spaces are 0 at program start.

Ops.Name: stores
Ops.Doc: store B to the Ath scratch space

Ops.Name: bnz
Ops.Doc: branch to TARGET if value A is not zero
Ops.DocExtra:
The `bnz` instruction opcode 0x40 is followed by two immediate data bytes which are a high byte first and low byte second which together form a 16 bit offset which the instruction may branch to. For a bnz instruction at `pc`, if the last element of the stack is not zero then branch to instruction at `pc + 3 + N`, else proceed to next instruction at `pc + 3`. Branch targets must be aligned instructions. (e.g. Branching to the second byte of a 2 byte op will be rejected.) Starting at v4, the offset is treated as a signed 16 bit integer allowing for backward branches and looping. In prior version (v1 to v3), branch offsets are limited to forward branches only, 0-0x7fff.

At v2 it became allowed to branch to the end of the program exactly after the last instruction: bnz to byte N (with 0-indexing) was illegal for a TEAL program with N bytes before v2, and is legal after it. This change eliminates the need for a last instruction of no-op as a branch target at the end. (Branching beyond the end--in other words, to a byte larger than N--is still illegal and will cause the program to fail.)

Ops.Name: bz
Ops.Doc: branch to TARGET if value A is zero
Ops.DocExtra: See `bnz` for details on how branches work. `bz` inverts the behavior of `bnz`.

Ops.Name: b
Ops.Doc: branch unconditionally to TARGET
Ops.DocExtra: See `bnz` for details on how branches work. `b` always jumps to the offset.

Ops.Name: return
Ops.Doc: use A as success value; end

Ops.Name: assert
Ops.Doc: immediately fail unless A is a non-zero number

Ops.Name: bury
Ops.Doc: replace the Nth value from the top of the stack with A. bury 0 fails.

Ops.Name: popn
Ops.Doc: remove N values from the top of the stack

Ops.Name: dupn
Ops.Doc: duplicate A, N times

Ops.Name: pop
Ops.Doc: discard A

Ops.Name: dup
Ops.Doc: duplicate A

Ops.Name: dup2
Ops.Doc: duplicate A and B

Ops.Name: dig
Ops.Doc: Nth value from the top of the stack. dig 0 is equivalent to dup

Ops.Name: swap
Ops.Doc: swaps A and B on stack

Ops.Name: select
Ops.Doc: selects one of two values based on top-of-stack: B if C != 0, else A

Ops.Name: cover
Ops.Doc: remove top of stack, and place it deeper in the stack such that N elements are above it. Fails if stack depth <= N.

Ops.Name: uncover
Ops.Doc: remove the value at depth N in the stack and shift above items down so the Nth deep value is on top of the stack. Fails if stack depth <= N.

Ops.Name: concat
Ops.Doc: join A and B
Ops.DocExtra: `concat` fails if the result would be greater than 4096 bytes.

Ops.Name: substring
Ops.Doc: A range of bytes from A starting at S up to but not including E. If E < S, or either is larger than the array length, the program fails

Ops.Name: substring3
Ops.Doc: A range of bytes from A starting at B up to but not including C. If C < B, or either is larger than the array length, the program fails

Ops.Name: getbit
Ops.Doc: Bth bit of (byte-array or integer) A. If B is greater than or equal to the bit length of the value (8*byte length), the program fails
Ops.DocExtra: see explanation of bit ordering in setbit

Ops.Name: setbit
Ops.Doc: Copy of (byte-array or integer) A, with the Bth bit set to (0 or 1) C. If B is greater than or equal to the bit length of the value (8*byte length), the program fails
Ops.DocExtra: When A is a uint64, index 0 is the least significant bit. Setting bit 3 to 1 on the integer 0 yields 8, or 2^3. When A is a byte array, index 0 is the leftmost bit of the leftmost byte. Setting bits 0 through 11 to 1 in a 4-byte-array of 0s yields the byte array 0xfff00000. Setting bit 3 to 1 on the 1-byte-array 0x00 yields the byte array 0x10.

Ops.Name: getbyte
Ops.Doc: Bth byte of A, as an integer. If B is greater than or equal to the array length, the program fails

Ops.Name: setbyte
Ops.Doc: Copy of A with the Bth byte set to small integer (between 0..255) C. If B is greater than or equal to the array length, the program fails

Ops.Name: extract
Ops.Doc: A range of bytes from A starting at S up to but not including S+L. If L is 0, then extract to the end of the string. If S or S+L is larger than the array length, the program fails

Ops.Name: extract3
Ops.Doc:
A range of bytes from A starting at B up to but not including B+C. If B+C is larger than the array length, the program fails
`extract3` can be called using `extract` with no immediates.

Ops.Name: extract_uint16
Ops.Doc: A uint16 formed from a range of big-endian bytes from A starting at B up to but not including B+2. If B+2 is larger than the array length, the program fails

Ops.Name: extract_uint32
Ops.Doc: A uint32 formed from a range of big-endian bytes from A starting at B up to but not including B+4. If B+4 is larger than the array length, the program fails

Ops.Name: extract_uint64
Ops.Doc: A uint64 formed from a range of big-endian bytes from A starting at B up to but not including B+8. If B+8 is larger than the array length, the program fails

Ops.Name: replace2
Ops.Doc:
Copy of A with the bytes starting at S replaced by the bytes of B. Fails if S+len(B) exceeds len(A)
`replace2` can be called using `replace` with 1 immediate.

Ops.Name: replace3
Ops.Doc:
Copy of A with the bytes starting at B replaced by the bytes of C. Fails if B+len(C) exceeds len(A)
`replace3` can be called using `replace` with no immediates.

Ops.Name: base64_decode
Ops.Doc: decode A which was base64-encoded using _encoding_ E. Fail if A is not base64 encoded with encoding E
Ops.DocExtra:
*Warning*: Usage should be restricted to very rare use cases. In almost all cases, smart contracts should directly handle non-encoded byte-strings.	This opcode should only be used in cases where base64 is the only available option, e.g. interoperability with a third-party that only signs base64 strings.

 Decodes A using the base64 encoding E. Specify the encoding with an immediate arg either as URL and Filename Safe (`URLEncoding`) or Standard (`StdEncoding`). See [RFC 4648 sections 4 and 5](https://rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4648.html#section-4). It is assumed that the encoding ends with the exact number of `=` padding characters as required by the RFC. When padding occurs, any unused pad bits in the encoding must be set to zero or the decoding will fail. The special cases of `\n` and `\r` are allowed but completely ignored. An error will result when attempting to decode a string with a character that is not in the encoding alphabet or not one of `=`, `\r`, or `\n`.

Ops.Name: json_ref
Ops.Doc: key B's value, of type R, from a [valid](jsonspec.md) utf-8 encoded json object A
Ops.DocExtra:
*Warning*: Usage should be restricted to very rare use cases, as JSON decoding is expensive and quite limited. In addition, JSON objects are large and not optimized for size.

Almost all smart contracts should use simpler and smaller methods (such as the [ABI](https://arc.algorand.foundation/ARCs/arc-0004). This opcode should only be used in cases where JSON is only available option, e.g. when a third-party only signs JSON.

Ops.Name: balance
Ops.Doc: balance for account A, in microalgos. The balance is observed after the effects of previous transactions in the group, and after the fee for the current transaction is deducted. Changes caused by inner transactions are observable immediately following `itxn_submit`
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ account address), _available_ application id (or, since v4, a Txn.ForeignApps offset). Return: value.

Ops.Name: app_opted_in
Ops.Doc: 1 if account A is opted in to application B, else 0
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ account address), _available_ application id (or, since v4, a Txn.ForeignApps offset). Return: 1 if opted in and 0 otherwise.

Ops.Name: app_local_get
Ops.Doc: local state of the key B in the current application in account A
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ account address), state key. Return: value. The value is zero (of type uint64) if the key does not exist.

Ops.Name: app_local_get_ex
Ops.Doc: X is the local state of application B, key C in account A. Y is 1 if key existed, else 0
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ account address), _available_ application id (or, since v4, a Txn.ForeignApps offset), state key. Return: did_exist flag (top of the stack, 1 if the application and key existed and 0 otherwise), value. The value is zero (of type uint64) if the key does not exist.

Ops.Name: app_global_get
Ops.Doc: global state of the key A in the current application
Ops.DocExtra: params: state key. Return: value. The value is zero (of type uint64) if the key does not exist.

Ops.Name: app_global_get_ex
Ops.Doc: X is the global state of application A, key B. Y is 1 if key existed, else 0
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.ForeignApps offset (or, since v4, an _available_ application id), state key. Return: did_exist flag (top of the stack, 1 if the application and key existed and 0 otherwise), value. The value is zero (of type uint64) if the key does not exist.

Ops.Name: app_local_put
Ops.Doc: write C to key B in account A's local state of the current application
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ account address), state key, value.

Ops.Name: app_global_put
Ops.Doc: write B to key A in the global state of the current application

Ops.Name: app_local_del
Ops.Doc: delete key B from account A's local state of the current application
Ops.DocExtra:
params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ account address), state key.

Deleting a key which is already absent has no effect on the application local state. (In particular, it does _not_ cause the program to fail.)

Ops.Name: app_global_del
Ops.Doc: delete key A from the global state of the current application
Ops.DocExtra:
params: state key.

Deleting a key which is already absent has no effect on the application global state. (In particular, it does _not_ cause the program to fail.)

Ops.Name: asset_holding_get
Ops.Doc: X is field F from account A's holding of asset B. Y is 1 if A is opted into B, else 0
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ address), asset id (or, since v4, a Txn.ForeignAssets offset). Return: did_exist flag (1 if the asset existed and 0 otherwise), value.

Ops.Name: asset_params_get
Ops.Doc: X is field F from asset A. Y is 1 if A exists, else 0
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.ForeignAssets offset (or, since v4, an _available_ asset id. Return: did_exist flag (1 if the asset existed and 0 otherwise), value.

Ops.Name: app_params_get
Ops.Doc: X is field F from app A. Y is 1 if A exists, else 0
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.ForeignApps offset or an _available_ app id. Return: did_exist flag (1 if the application existed and 0 otherwise), value.

Ops.Name: acct_params_get
Ops.Doc: X is field F from account A. Y is 1 if A owns positive algos, else 0

Ops.Name: voter_params_get
Ops.Doc: X is field F from online account A as of the balance round: 320 rounds before the current round. Y is 1 if A had positive algos online in the agreement round, else Y is 0 and X is a type specific zero-value

Ops.Name: online_stake
Ops.Doc: the total online stake in the agreement round

Ops.Name: min_balance
Ops.Doc: minimum required balance for account A, in microalgos. Required balance is affected by ASA, App, and Box usage. When creating or opting into an app, the minimum balance grows before the app code runs, therefore the increase is visible there. When deleting or closing out, the minimum balance decreases after the app executes. Changes caused by inner transactions or box usage are observable immediately following the opcode effecting the change.
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ account address), _available_ application id (or, since v4, a Txn.ForeignApps offset). Return: value.

Ops.Name: pushbytes
Ops.Doc: immediate BYTES
Ops.DocExtra: pushbytes args are not added to the bytecblock during assembly processes

Ops.Name: pushint
Ops.Doc: immediate UINT
Ops.DocExtra: pushint args are not added to the intcblock during assembly processes

Ops.Name: pushbytess
Ops.Doc: push sequences of immediate byte arrays to stack (first byte array being deepest)
Ops.DocExtra: pushbytess args are not added to the bytecblock during assembly processes

Ops.Name: pushints
Ops.Doc: push sequence of immediate uints to stack in the order they appear (first uint being deepest)
Ops.DocExtra: pushints args are not added to the intcblock during assembly processes

Ops.Name: ed25519verify_bare
Ops.Doc: for (data A, signature B, pubkey C) verify the signature of the data against the pubkey => {0 or 1}

Ops.Name: falcon_verify
Ops.Doc: for (data A, compressed-format signature B, pubkey C) verify the signature of data against the pubkey => {0 or 1}

Ops.Name: callsub
Ops.Doc: branch unconditionally to TARGET, saving the next instruction on the call stack
Ops.DocExtra: The call stack is separate from the data stack. Only `callsub`, `retsub`, and `proto` manipulate it.

Ops.Name: retsub
Ops.Doc: pop the top instruction from the call stack and branch to it
Ops.DocExtra: If the current frame was prepared by `proto A R`, `retsub` will remove the 'A' arguments from the stack, move the `R` return values down, and pop any stack locations above the relocated return values.

Ops.Name: proto
Ops.Doc: Prepare top call frame for a retsub that will assume A args and R return values.
Ops.DocExtra: Fails unless the last instruction executed was a `callsub`.

Ops.Name: frame_dig
Ops.Doc: Nth (signed) value from the frame pointer.

Ops.Name: frame_bury
Ops.Doc: replace the Nth (signed) value from the frame pointer in the stack with A

Ops.Name: switch
Ops.Doc: branch to the Ath label. Continue at following instruction if index A exceeds the number of labels.

Ops.Name: match
Ops.Doc: given match cases from A[1] to A[N], branch to the Ith label where A[I] = B. Continue to the following instruction if no matches are found.
Ops.DocExtra: `match` consumes N+1 values from the stack. Let the top stack value be B. The following N values represent an ordered list of match cases/constants (A), where the first value (A[0]) is the deepest in the stack. The immediate arguments are an ordered list of N labels (T). `match` will branch to target T[I], where A[I] = B. If there are no matches then execution continues on to the next instruction.

Ops.Name: shl
Ops.Doc: A times 2^B, modulo 2^64

Ops.Name: shr
Ops.Doc: A divided by 2^B

Ops.Name: sqrt
Ops.Doc: The largest integer I such that I^2 <= A

Ops.Name: bitlen
Ops.Doc: The highest set bit in A. If A is a byte-array, it is interpreted as a big-endian unsigned integer. bitlen of 0 is 0, bitlen of 8 is 4
Ops.DocExtra: bitlen interprets arrays as big-endian integers, unlike setbit/getbit

Ops.Name: exp
Ops.Doc: A raised to the Bth power. Fail if A == B == 0 and on overflow

Ops.Name: expw
Ops.Doc: A raised to the Bth power as a 128-bit result in two uint64s. X is the high 64 bits, Y is the low. Fail if A == B == 0 or if the results exceeds 2^128-1

Ops.Name: bsqrt
Ops.Doc: The largest integer I such that I^2 <= A. A and I are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: divw
Ops.Doc: A,B / C. Fail if C == 0 or if result overflows.
Ops.DocExtra: The notation A,B indicates that A and B are interpreted as a uint128 value, with A as the high uint64 and B the low.

Ops.Name: sha3_256
Ops.Doc: SHA3_256 hash of value A, yields [32]byte

Ops.Name: b+
Ops.Doc: A plus B. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: b-
Ops.Doc: A minus B. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers. Fail on underflow.

Ops.Name: b/
Ops.Doc: A divided by B (truncated division). A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers. Fail if B is zero.

Ops.Name: b*
Ops.Doc: A times B. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers.

Ops.Name: b<
Ops.Doc: 1 if A is less than B, else 0. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: b>
Ops.Doc: 1 if A is greater than B, else 0. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: b<=
Ops.Doc: 1 if A is less than or equal to B, else 0. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: b>=
Ops.Doc: 1 if A is greater than or equal to B, else 0. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: b==
Ops.Doc: 1 if A is equal to B, else 0. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: b!=
Ops.Doc: 0 if A is equal to B, else 1. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: b%
Ops.Doc: A modulo B. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers. Fail if B is zero.

Ops.Name: b|
Ops.Doc: A bitwise-or B. A and B are zero-left extended to the greater of their lengths

Ops.Name: b&
Ops.Doc: A bitwise-and B. A and B are zero-left extended to the greater of their lengths

Ops.Name: b^
Ops.Doc: A bitwise-xor B. A and B are zero-left extended to the greater of their lengths

Ops.Name: b~
Ops.Doc: A with all bits inverted

Ops.Name: bzero
Ops.Doc: zero filled byte-array of length A

Ops.Name: log
Ops.Doc: write A to log state of the current application
Ops.DocExtra: `log` fails if called more than MaxLogCalls times in a program, or if the sum of logged bytes exceeds 1024 bytes.

Ops.Name: itxn_begin
Ops.Doc: begin preparation of a new inner transaction in a new transaction group
Ops.DocExtra: `itxn_begin` initializes Sender to the application address; Fee to the minimum allowable, taking into account MinTxnFee and credit from overpaying in earlier transactions; FirstValid/LastValid to the values in the invoking transaction, and all other fields to zero or empty values.

Ops.Name: itxn_field
Ops.Doc: set field F of the current inner transaction to A
Ops.DocExtra: `itxn_field` fails if A is of the wrong type for F, including a byte array of the wrong size for use as an address when F is an address field. `itxn_field` also fails if A is an account, asset, or app that is not _available_, or an attempt is made extend an array field beyond the limit imposed by consensus parameters. (Addresses set into asset params of acfg transactions need not be _available_.)

Ops.Name: itxn_submit
Ops.Doc: execute the current inner transaction group. Fail if executing this group would exceed the inner transaction limit, or if any transaction in the group fails.
Ops.DocExtra: `itxn_submit` resets the current transaction so that it can not be resubmitted. A new `itxn_begin` is required to prepare another inner transaction.

Ops.Name: itxn
Ops.Doc: field F of the last inner transaction

Ops.Name: itxna
Ops.Doc: Ith value of the array field F of the last inner transaction

Ops.Name: itxn_next
Ops.Doc: begin preparation of a new inner transaction in the same transaction group
Ops.DocExtra: `itxn_next` initializes the transaction exactly as `itxn_begin` does

Ops.Name: gitxn
Ops.Doc: field F of the Tth transaction in the last inner group submitted

Ops.Name: gitxna
Ops.Doc: Ith value of the array field F from the Tth transaction in the last inner group submitted

Ops.Name: box_create
Ops.Doc: create a box named A, of length B. Fail if the name A is empty or B exceeds 32,768. Returns 0 if A already existed, else 1
Ops.DocExtra: Newly created boxes are filled with 0 bytes. `box_create` will fail if the referenced box already exists with a different size. Otherwise, existing boxes are unchanged by `box_create`.

Ops.Name: box_extract
Ops.Doc: read C bytes from box A, starting at offset B. Fail if A does not exist, or the byte range is outside A's size.

Ops.Name: box_replace
Ops.Doc: write byte-array C into box A, starting at offset B. Fail if A does not exist, or the byte range is outside A's size.

Ops.Name: box_del
Ops.Doc: delete box named A if it exists. Return 1 if A existed, 0 otherwise

Ops.Name: box_len
Ops.Doc: X is the length of box A if A exists, else 0. Y is 1 if A exists, else 0.

Ops.Name: box_get
Ops.Doc: X is the contents of box A if A exists, else ''. Y is 1 if A exists, else 0.
Ops.DocExtra: For boxes that exceed 4,096 bytes, consider `box_create`, `box_extract`, and `box_replace`

Ops.Name: box_put
Ops.Doc: replaces the contents of box A with byte-array B. Fails if A exists and len(B) != len(box A). Creates A if it does not exist
Ops.DocExtra: For boxes that exceed 4,096 bytes, consider `box_create`, `box_extract`, and `box_replace`

Ops.Name: txnas
Ops.Doc: Ath value of the array field F of the current transaction

Ops.Name: gtxnas
Ops.Doc: Ath value of the array field F from the Tth transaction in the current group

Ops.Name: gtxnsas
Ops.Doc: Bth value of the array field F from the Ath transaction in the current group

Ops.Name: args
Ops.Doc: Ath LogicSig argument

Ops.Name: gloadss
Ops.Doc: Bth scratch space value of the Ath transaction in the current group

Ops.Name: itxnas
Ops.Doc: Ath value of the array field F of the last inner transaction

Ops.Name: gitxnas
Ops.Doc: Ath value of the array field F from the Tth transaction in the last inner group submitted

Ops.Name: vrf_verify
Ops.Doc: Verify the proof B of message A against pubkey C. Returns vrf output and verification flag.
Ops.DocExtra: `VrfAlgorand` is the VRF used in Algorand. It is ECVRF-ED25519-SHA512-Elligator2, specified in the IETF internet draft [draft-irtf-cfrg-vrf-03](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-irtf-cfrg-vrf/03/).

Ops.Name: block
Ops.Doc: field F of block A. Fail unless A falls between txn.LastValid-1002 and txn.FirstValid (exclusive)

Ops.Name: box_splice
Ops.Doc: set box A to contain its previous bytes up to index B, followed by D, followed by the original bytes of A that began at index B+C.
Ops.DocExtra: Boxes are of constant length. If C < len(D), then len(D)-C bytes will be removed from the end. If C > len(D), zero bytes will be appended to the end to reach the box length.

Ops.Name: box_resize
Ops.Doc: change the size of box named A to be of length B, adding zero bytes to end or removing bytes from the end, as needed. Fail if the name A is empty, A is not an existing box, or B exceeds 32,768.

Ops.Name: ec_add
Ops.Doc: for curve points A and B, return the curve point A + B
Ops.DocExtra:
A and B are curve points in affine representation: field element X concatenated with field element Y. Field element `Z` is encoded as follows.
For the base field elements (Fp), `Z` is encoded as a big-endian number and must be lower than the field modulus.
For the quadratic field extension (Fp2), `Z` is encoded as the concatenation of the individual encoding of the coefficients. For an Fp2 element of the form `Z = Z0 + Z1 i`, where `i` is a formal quadratic non-residue, the encoding of Z is the concatenation of the encoding of `Z0` and `Z1` in this order. (`Z0` and `Z1` must be less than the field modulus).

The point at infinity is encoded as `(X,Y) = (0,0)`.
Groups G1 and G2 are denoted additively.

Fails if A or B is not in G.
A and/or B are allowed to be the point at infinity.
Does _not_ check if A and B are in the main prime-order subgroup.

Ops.Name: ec_scalar_mul
Ops.Doc: for curve point A and scalar B, return the curve point BA, the point A multiplied by the scalar B.
Ops.DocExtra: A is a curve point encoded and checked as described in `ec_add`. Scalar B is interpreted as a big-endian unsigned integer. Fails if B exceeds 32 bytes.

Ops.Name: ec_pairing_check
Ops.DocCost: BN254g1=8000 + 7400 per 64 bytes of B; BN254g2=8000 + 7400 per 128 bytes of B; BLS12_381g1=13000 + 10000 per 96 bytes of B; BLS12_381g2=13000 + 10000 per 192 bytes of B
Ops.Doc: 1 if the product of the pairing of each point in A with its respective point in B is equal to the identity element of the target group Gt, else 0
Ops.DocExtra: A and B are concatenated points, encoded and checked as described in `ec_add`. A contains points of the group G, B contains points of the associated group (G2 if G is G1, and vice versa). Fails if A and B have a different number of points, or if any point is not in its described group or outside the main prime-order subgroup - a stronger condition than other opcodes. AVM values are limited to 4096 bytes, so `ec_pairing_check` is limited by the size of the points in the groups being operated upon.

Ops.Name: ec_multi_scalar_mul
Ops.DocCost: BN254g1=3600 + 90 per 32 bytes of B; BN254g2=7200 + 270 per 32 bytes of B; BLS12_381g1=6500 + 95 per 32 bytes of B; BLS12_381g2=14850 + 485 per 32 bytes of B
Ops.Doc: for curve points A and scalars B, return curve point B0A0 + B1A1 + B2A2 + ... + BnAn
Ops.DocExtra:
A is a list of concatenated points, encoded and checked as described in `ec_add`. B is a list of concatenated scalars which, unlike ec_scalar_mul, must all be exactly 32 bytes long.
The name `ec_multi_scalar_mul` was chosen to reflect common usage, but a more consistent name would be `ec_multi_scalar_mul`. AVM values are limited to 4096 bytes, so `ec_multi_scalar_mul` is limited by the size of the points in the group being operated upon.

Ops.Name: ec_subgroup_check
Ops.Doc: 1 if A is in the main prime-order subgroup of G (including the point at infinity) else 0. Program fails if A is not in G at all.

Ops.Name: ec_map_to
Ops.Doc: maps field element A to group G
Ops.DocExtra:
BN254 points are mapped by the SVDW map. BLS12-381 points are mapped by the SSWU map.
G1 element inputs are base field elements and G2 element inputs are quadratic field elements, with nearly the same encoding rules (for field elements) as defined in `ec_add`. There is one difference of encoding rule: G1 element inputs do not need to be 0-padded if they fit in less than 32 bytes for BN254 and less than 48 bytes for BLS12-381. (As usual, the empty byte array represents 0.) G2 elements inputs need to be always have the required size.

Ops.Name: mimc
Ops.DocCost: BN254Mp110=10 + 550 per 32 bytes of A; BLS12_381Mp111=10 + 550 per 32 bytes of A
Ops.Doc: MiMC hash of scalars A, using curve and parameters specified by configuration C
Ops.DocExtra:
A is a list of concatenated 32 byte big-endian unsigned integer scalars.  Fail if A's length is not a multiple of 32 or any element exceeds the curve modulus.

The MiMC hash function has known collisions since any input which is a multiple of the elliptic curve modulus will hash to the same value. MiMC is thus not a general purpose hash function, but meant to be used in zero knowledge applications to match a zk-circuit implementation.
